Introduction

Every part of our life has been altered by technological advancements in the digital arena, from shopping to working with co-workers, connecting with friends, pleasure, and finance management [2].

Identity management has always been a major topic of discussion since the inception of the Internet, with billions of dollars spent on usability, privacy, and security. In 2020, the worldwide identity and access management market was estimated to be worth USD 12.26 billion. In 2021-2028, the market is expected to increase at a CAGR of 14.5%, from USD13.41 billion in 2021 to USD34.52 billion in 2028.

Digital identification is crucial to most social and commercial transactions in today’s data-driven society. This determines how users engage in the digital world. Despite this significant investment, the three Cs – costly, cumbersome, and challenging – continue to plague digital identity management.

Furthermore, traditional identity systems remain extremely vulnerable, with single points of failure that attract ongoing attempts to have access to the whole pool of high-value data. Thus, users’ experience is dramatically harmed as organizations prioritize cybersecurity, identity protection, and compliance management.

Individuals are responsible for managing various internet IDs and passwords and a variety of documents such as passports, Social Security cards, driver’s licenses, and medical insurance cards.
